user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.2 is: Functions shall not call themselves, either directly or indirectly.

</misra_rule>

Another agent reported that the target code violated the Rule 17.2.
Here is the comment from the agent.
<violation scenario>
The code performs an indirect call through a function pointer (StubPtr->Data.Cb.Ptr.VaHook). If that pointer is ever set to the same function (UT_DefaultStubImplWithArgs) or to a function that (possibly via other pointers) calls UT_DefaultStubImplWithArgs, this becomes an indirect self-call and thus violates MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.2. Example violation: registering UT_DefaultStubImplWithArgs as the VaHook so the runtime call path is UT_DefaultStubImplWithArgs -> VaHook (points to UT_DefaultStubImplWithArgs) -> UT_DefaultStubImplWithArgs (recursion).
</violation scenario>

Your job is to insert logging code to capture the control flow and state information of the program.
Insert logging code so that other agents can reproduce and get evidence for the violation scenario.
<response format>
- test_code: a modified UtAssert_Message code that contains useful probe functions that print useful logs to a file "/tmp/logs/870.txt". The logs should contain the control path and state information of the violation scenario. If test code is not required to validate the scenario, you can leave this blank.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of UtAssert_Message:
```c
void UtAssert_Message(uint8 MessageType, const char *File, uint32 Line, const char *Spec, ...)
{
    va_list     va;
    char        FinalMessage[256];
    const char *BaseName;
    size_t      MsgLen;

    if (File != NULL)
    {
        BaseName = strrchr(File, '/');
        if (BaseName == NULL)
        {
            BaseName = File;
        }
        else
        {
            ++BaseName;
        }
        snprintf(FinalMessage, sizeof(FinalMessage), "%s:%u:", BaseName, (unsigned int)Line);
        MsgLen = strlen(FinalMessage);
    }
    else
    {
        MsgLen = 0;
    }

    va_start(va, Spec);
    vsnprintf(&FinalMessage[MsgLen], sizeof(FinalMessage) - MsgLen, Spec, va);
    va_end(va);

    UT_BSP_DoText(MessageType, FinalMessage);
}
```
</target_code>

<instruction>

Please provide the modified UtAssert_Message code.

The information below explains how I’ll use the function you provide. Please use it as a reference when generating code.
1. Replacement
  - I will parse your function and replace the original UtAssert_Message with it.
  - Your function must have the exact same signature as UtAssert_Message.
  - It must be a complete, self-contained definition; (no omissions, placeholders (e.g., "..."), or comments indicating skipped/omitted logic.)
2. Logging / reachability
  - I will run a test suite that is guaranteed to call UtAssert_Message to check logs.
  - Your function MUST preserve the original logic of UtAssert_Message as much as possible.
  - The log output must not be empty. Even if you are verifying dead code, UtAssert_Message will be reached; insert a minimal probe/log to demonstrate that the target function was entered.
3. Coverage
  - I will run the same test suite to measure coverage.
  - Test outcomes must match those of the original code.
  - If reproducing the rule violation necessarily causes a crash (e.g., the violation inherently triggers a crash), that is acceptable; otherwise, your function should not crash under the existing test suite so coverage can be measured.
4. Test code constraints
  - The test code MUST preserve the original logic of UtAssert_Message as much as possible.
  - DO NOT introduce new violations to demonstrate your scenario.
  - The test code MUST be compilable and executable.
  - The test code MUST include line breaks.
  - You MUST NOT define the main function.
  - You MUST NOT define macros.
  - You MUST NOT REDEFINE any existing identifiers, such as macros, static/global variables, or functions.
  - Do not break string literals or include stray/unmatched double quotes; the code must parse cleanly with no quote-related errors.

These are common mistakes of generated codes. Do not make these mistakes:
- Redefining existing functions, variables, types, or macros.
- Broken string literals or unmatched quotes.
- Invoking undeclared function.
- Using undeclared member in a struct.
- Invoking functions with wrong parameter type.

</instruction>
